review.title: An Ontological Architecture for Orbital Debris Data
review.abstract: The orbital debris problem presents an opportunity for inter-agency and international cooperation toward the mutually beneficial goals of debris prevention, mitigation, remediation, and improved space situational awareness (SSA). Achieving these goals requires sharing orbital debris and other SSA data. Toward this, I present an ontological architecture for the orbital debris domain, taking steps in the creation of an orbital debris ontology (ODO). The purpose of this ontological system is to (I) represent general orbital debris and SSA domain knowledge, (II) structure, and standardize where needed, orbital data and terminology, and (III) foster semantic interoperability and data-sharing. In doing so I hope to (IV) contribute to solving the orbital debris problem, improving peaceful global SSA, and ensuring safe space travel for future generations.

sections.text: Achieving these goals requires the sharing of orbital waste and other SSA data. To this end, I will present an ontological architecture for the orbital waste sector and take steps to create an orbital waste ontology (ODO), the purpose of which is to (I) present general orbital waste and SSA domain knowledge, (II) standardize the structure and, where appropriate, orbital data and terminology, and (III) promote semantic interoperability and data sharing, thereby hoping to (IV) contribute to solving the orbital waste problem, improve peaceful global SSA and ensure safe space travel for future generations. Keywords: orbital waste; space waste; astroinformatics; ontology; ontological engineering; space awareness; semantics; data sharing.

sections.heading: 5. ONTOLOGY MODULES FOR ORBITAL DEBRIS
sections.text: This section summarizes some relevant domain ontologies for an ontology of orbital debris and SSA. Each domain ontology - ontologies of a specific topic or universe of discourse - should have: (i) category and relationship terms, (ii) definitions of natural language, as well as predictable semantics, and (iii) a hierarchical structure.

sections.heading: Q2 What types of debris are currently in orbit?
sections.text: For example, fragments of spacecraft, whole rocket body parts, mission-related artifacts (e.g. astronaut gloves, tools), etc.

sections.heading: Q3 What are the physical, intentional and social properties of orbital debris?
sections.text: Physical characteristics (relative or otherwise) include size, shape, mass, position, posture, velocity, orbital characteristics, etc. Intentional and social characteristics include cognitive attributions, as well as socially constructed or legal characteristics and relationships such as ownership. This also includes space policy, which governs the management of debris.

sections.heading: Q4 What is an ontological characterization of orbital debris?
sections.text: Answering this means a higher level (more general) classification and definition of "Debris" objects in the Earth. "There is an answer to the following question: What type of entity is orbital waste - a physical object, material artifacts, a role,...?" Orbital deposits can be characterized as types of physical objects, i.e., spatially limited objects that have some material properties. This is intuitive because the concept (and talk) of deposits brings material things to mind. But deeper ontological analyses yield another possibility. Debris can be modeled as a role that we ascribe to physical objects in orbit, a role played by the object in terms of social conventions, processes, and systems. One could justify this alternative characterization as follow-up systems. Common definitions describe debris as useless or dysfunctional.

sections.heading: ASTRONOMY ONTOLOGIES
sections.text: One or more astronomical ontologies should include general terms for astronomical phenomena studied by astronomers. The most prominent astronomical units relevant to ODO are natural celestial bodies, i.e. planets. A broader space situation perception ontology (SSAO) will include classes for more astronomical entities, such as space weather phenomena, asteroids and comets, etc. Existing ontologies include astronomical ontologies (astronomy / science ontology), and the International Virtual Observatory Alliance (IVOA) ontology of astronomical object types. Together, this set of ontologies includes astronomical objects, scientific units, and so on. Depending on the domain-neutral distinctions, an astronomical ontology can be in the form of two related star ontologies.

sections.heading: CELESTIAL MECHANICS & ASTRODYNAMICS ONTOLOGIES
sections.text: Astrodynamics Ontology represents the knowledge of astrodynamics, i.e., the movement of human objects in space. This is a primary focus for ODO because we are interested in current and future orbital states (position, velocity, etc.).Instance data includes data on specific orbital elements that define the orbits of individual spacecraft, debris, and other space objects in one or more time periods. Given the common scientific basis, astrodynamics is closely related to celestial mechanics.

sections.heading: 5.3 DATA TYPE, INFORMATION & GEOMETRIC ENTITY ONTOLOGIES
sections.text: Data / information sontologies and geometric ontologies represent data types, standard units, data formats, information objects (or units), and geometric objects. Coordinate systems designed as geometric constructs must be represented in these ontologies. Note that the concept of a data or information unit is not entirely clear and problem-free, but it will be enough to clarify this point. It is also unclear whether geometric units are correctly classified as one type of these units, types of abstracts, cognitive artifacts, or other. Agencies such as NASA and the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) are notable sources of this knowledge. Formal representations of this type of units also exist. IVOA and UMD ontologies, for example, have measurement and unit parts, and NASA's Semantic Web for Earth Environmental Terminology (SWEET) ontologies include a number of unit terms.

The green rectangular image represents individual space object catalogs (orbital debris information systems) that contain instance data on certain deceased satellites, spacecraft and other space objects considered orbital debris. Instance data containing sensor data of actual space objects should be provided with ODO generic categories to provide formal semantics to the user and the computational system. Domain-specific ontologies can be summarized by more general ontologies and ontology, the latter consisting of domain-neutral categories and relationships.

sections.heading: 7. CONCLUSION
sections.text: By improving our situational awareness of the orbital environment, we are better able to solve the space junk threat and improve space security. Given (i) the existence of different situational information systems from different space agencies, (ii) heterogeneous data and data formats, (iii) the gaps in orbital coverage and therefore (iv) our limited knowledge of orbital junk and the broader population of space objects, the sharing of space junk data should increase a peaceful global SSA. To achieve these goals, I have presented an ontological architecture for the orbital debris domain and outlined some requirements for orbital debris ontology (ODO). The purpose of ODO (or a broader SSA ontology) is to represent general knowledge about and entities within the orbital debris domain and the SSA domain.

Ontology or Ontological engineering (Staab and Studer 2009) in computer science is related to knowledge representation and informatics. The ontology development process involves domain research, concept analysis, a terminology/vocabulary, and the explicit specification of at least an understanding of the given domain of interest. The terms in the taxonomy, their definitions and the interrelationships between them (or that which the terms denote), are intended to express or capture the domain. This results in a logically formalized taxonomical structure that can be computationally reasoned over. Ontology development is an ongoing iterative process that requires curation, quality-control, revision and updating. This is particularly necessary for ontologies of the sciences, e.g., astronomy, where knowledge is updated and corrected, and where new discoveries are made over time. See Pinto and Martins (2004) for an account of the different stages of ontology building.
